The first question? Mostly… no. Buckle up, this is a long answer. First of all, what humans can discern with their eyes is mostly only apparent brightness of a star (how bright the star looks. It’s an actual astronomy term). You can’t see really the color, and color is key. We’ll get to that in a second.

So, apparent brightness. Is it useful? Temperature of stars is loosely related to luminosity (another actual astronomy term. It’s like the “absolute brightness” of a star, or how much power, it’s outputting in all directions. Not just in the direction of your eye.) If you’re lucky and you’re seeing stars on the main sequence, oh, right. What’s the main sequence?

There’s a useful chart called the Hertzprung-Russell Diagram (google images it!) that shows temperature vs luminosity of stars. Temperature doesn’t necessarily correlate with luminosity. You’ve got these stars that are pretty normal and are on the “main sequence” that shows a linear-ish relationship between temperature and luminosity. Then there are other stars OFF the main sequence like Red Giants that are really bright but really cool. So you can’t necessarily count on temperature being related to luminosity. You ALSO can’t count on luminosity being related to apparent brightness, the thing you actually see, because stars appear dimmer when they are further away. You could have a really hot bright star far away and a really dim cool star close by and they would look the same brightness in the sky. So you can’t rely on brightness. Poop.

You can rely on color. You need to know the peak color of a star’s emission spectrum. That will tell you the temperature. Stars approximate black bodies which means that their peak wavelength correlates with their temperature. But the thing is, you can’t make out peak temperature with your naked eye because it’s emitting lots of colors even when it’s emitting the most of one color. So it ends up looking white. For example our star, our sun, we say it emits white light, but it actually peaks in green.

So to learn the temperature of a star, you need to measure its spectrum with a telescopey thing. But EVEN THEN you can’t necessarily tell which star is hottest based on the peak of the spectrum because some stars that are really far away are redshifted by really complicated effects from the expansion of the universe. Stars that are far away LOOK redder (if you could see the peak color of a star by looking). What you need to do then is look at detail in the spectrum, see where signature emission and absorption peaks are from elements like hydrogen, correct for redshift of the start to adjust the peak to the right color and THEN you can tell the temperature. Phew. Astronomers have a lot to do.

Important is that both liquids and solids are atoms "touching" each other (being at distances similar to their van der Waals radii). So the question is, is packing in a disordered conformation more or less dense than in an ordered conformation? When we're trying to pack our clothes, we are dealing with the same dilemma, and definitely total chaos is bad, but some "ordered" packing is obviously quite bad at filling space and others are quite good. So if you think about it this way, it's not so surprising that some liquids are less dense than solids and some more dense. At least IMO. While, yes, the water level would ultimately be at equilibrium lower than when the ice cube is floating, it would not be a sudden transition. Rather what happens is that at some point the cube will shift from floating, to not floating. That is, at some point the density of the ice cube and diamond will precisely match that of the water. Now the exact point would depend on how large the diamond is, but using your value of 3.5 g/cm^3 it will be roughly when the volume of ice is 31.25 the volume of the diamond.

It seems high, but that’s because ice has just over 90% the density of water. It’s buoyant, but it can only support a small amount of denser material. So one cm^3 of diamond (3.5g) would require 31.25 cm^3 of ice to be neutral buoyancy, for a total volume of 32.25 cm^3.

But it’s not like the ice would melt all at once. Once it hits this threshold, it would continue to melt. Increasing the density of the cube slowly, over time. So it would sink at this point, and continue to shrink. However since the density keeps increasing (as volume decreases) the water level would drop over time, in roughly linear fashion, until all the ice is melted and the new equilibrium is reached.

So there is no sudden shift, just continuous change from one equilibrium state, to another equilibrium state.

Yes, it's possible to determine the temperature of a star by looking at the spectrum of light it emits. All objects above 0K (absolute zero) emit blackbody radiation. This is what makes incandescent light bulbs glow, and is how infrared thermometers (and thermal cameras) measure the temperature of an object. The distribution of wavelengths an object emits due to blackbody radiation is a function of its temperature, so measuring this distribution for a given object will tell you how hot it is.

Of course, this assumes that the star in question has a constant temperature. If the temperature changes, the light characteristic of that new temperature will take an amount of time proportional to the star's distance to reach the observer, so you'd be measuring what the temperature of the star was - not is.
